Importing and Exporting Company Snapshots

Overview

MetalAccounting allows all users to capture the current state of a company and all its accounts, periods, and journal entries in a snapshot. This data is downloaded as a plain text file and can subsiquently be imported as a carbon copy by you and others.

Security

The downloaded text file is not readable or editable by humans. The text data is first obfuscated with a cryptographically secure hashing algorithm (sha-2) then digitally signed with a separate key. No computerized system is 100% secure from bad actors; however, snapshots are prohibitively difficult to tamper with. If MetalAccounting successfully imports a company from a snapshot you can be sure that the text data had not been modified.

Using Snapshots For Graded Assignments and Exams

Spapshots are a suitable medium for submitting graded work due in part to the security implementation described above. Additionally, snapshots maintain a history of when they were imported/exported and which user ID did the action. Companies created from snapshots maintain this history when they are re-exported. The timestamped history is set by the MetalAccounting server (not the web browser) and is baked into the snapshot's scrambled text data. Timestamps are based on UTC and offset to match your browser's timezone settings. Like snapshots, the history of user activity is prohibitively tamper-proof. MetalAccounting offers a simple tool for viewing a snapshots history of user actions.

The below series of actions would generate the following history

  1. Jan 1, 2020 @ 1:30pm you generate a snapshot which serves as the starting point for an exam
  2. Jan 15, 2020 @ 4:00pm the exam starts and a student imports the snapshot
  3. Jan 15, 2020 @ 5:20pm the exam ends and the student submits their exported work
  4. Jan 17, 2020 @ 11:45am you view the snapshot's user history before importing
Timestamp User ID Event
Jan 1, 2020 1:30 PM YOU export
Jan 15, 2020 4:00 PM A3FC177D import
Jan 15, 2020 5:20 PM A3FC177D export

An instance of cheating between students A3FC177D and CFF378DA might look like this when viewing CFF378DA's submitted snapshot:
Timestamp User ID Event
Jan 1, 2020 1:30 PM YOU export
Jan 15, 2020 4:00 PM A3FC177D import
Jan 15, 2020 5:10 PM A3FC177D export
Jan 15, 2020 5:12 PM CFF378DA import
Jan 15, 2020 5:20 PM CFF378DA export

How Snapshots are Encoded and Decoded

Note: Understanding how snapshots are created is not required to use them.

First, your company, its associated accounts, periods, jounral entries, and meta data is serialized as JSON. JSON is a simple, human readale data format that represents arbitrary data as plain text. A company encoded as JSON text might look something like this:

{ "meta":{ jtw_claims:... "version":1, "user_history":[ { "user":"AB49FFCA", "event":"export", "timestamp":"2020-01-01T09:23:15-00:00" } ] }, "company":{ "name":"XYZ Corp." }, "accounts":[ { "id":1, "name":"cash", "type":"asset", "is_current":true, "is_contra":false, "is_operational":null, "tag":"cash" }, { "id":2, "name":"Common Stock", "type":"equity", "is_current":null, "is_contra":false, "is_operational":null, "tag":null, } ] "periods":[ { "id":1, "start":"2020-01-01", "end":"2020-03-31" } ], "journal_entries":[ { "id":1, "period_id":1, "date":"2020-01-15", "memo":"Investors invested." } ] "journal_entry_lines":[ { "id":1, "journal_entry_id":1, "account_id":1, "type":"debit", "amount":100000 }, { "id":2, "journal_entry_id":1, "account_id":2, "type":"credit", "amount":100000 } ] }

The next step is to convert the unsecured JSON text into a JSON web token (JWT). The scrambled output is seeded from SECRET_KEY_A. Undoing the scrampble is not trivial to do without knowing SECRET_KEY_A. Once encoded as a JWT, the company and its data is no longer human readable. It will look something like this:.

eydfhdsSFGAHGDSafdgsher436ytENdgmYKUN.efsvfgkgfdecWrabvgRTtbrnutko,uymiopzwxvlASDascwnuavEEVSAFWCfsh65crgt45wb.fagsaf4231zgcarxEEXs

Users will not be able to read or modify the JWT unless they also know SECRET_KEY_A, which is hidden away on a MetalAccounting server.

Finally the encoded claims and meta data signed with SECRET_KEY_B, adding a small secure checksum to the and of JWT. eydfhdsSFGAHGDSafdgsher436ytENdgmYKUN.efsvfgkgfdecWrabvgRTtbrnutko,uymiopzwxvlASDascwnuavEEVSAFWCfsh65crgt45wb.fagsaf4231zgcarxEEXs:SECURE_CHECK_SUM
